head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #15

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #15 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: July 8 Thursday. From the Port. WSW1m. across a small lac to a pt – then WbN1m. to a pt on ye Rt in a Chanl like a River – NWbW½ to a pt on Lt – went rod ye pt to a Grassy swamp (being a Strait into another lac) pass'd thro't it witht debarking & went in a small lac NWbW1m. to a pt on ye Rt having a deep Bay with Is on Rt & a narrow stony Chanl on ye Left – NWbW1m. to a pt on Lt Rt the left a bay on ye Rt – rod ye pt WbN1m. to a narrow Passage like a Creek on ye Lt went down ye Currt in it 2m. at the end of wch a Grassy neck which opens into lac des morts – turn'd rod upon ye Rt & went WSW[,] along ye NW shore 2½ to a grassy pt leaving 2 rocks & 2 small Is on ye Rt – WbN1½ to another pt of Grass on ye Rt a deep bay on the Lt then rod ye pt & across a bay NWbN¾ – then cross'd in a bay NW3m. then turn'd off on the Lt & went WSW to ye pt of an Id on Rt 2 bays & 2 Is on Rt then Wt 3 to a pt opposite an old Fort, where a Mr Roy winter'd 2 years ago 2 Is on Lt & deep bay on Rt – hence to a pt of Stones 1½ WNW to a deep bay on Rt Is & stones on Lt – turn'd rod ye pt & went NbW in a bay 2m (some burnt woods of a red colour on Lt) to a wide strai[t,] went in it WNW near ½ m. – then turn'd rod an Id on Rt & went NNE1m. to 2 black rocks on ye shore, left them on ye Rt & turn'd on ye Lt into a narrow Channel with stony shores a short distance in it debark'd, & pass'd the Canoe between some Stones in a narrow neck – here the Currt runs Etly – then enter'd a small lac, cross'd it WNW1½ to a broad Channel, went in it WbN3, (where we were stopp'd by rain at 11h. a.m.)[.]

9 Friday. Left the Strait & cross'd a small lac to a pt of high land on Lt WbN1m, pass'd a bay on ye Lt & an Id on Rt – then Wt 1½ to the pt on an I. on Lt Channl ¾ m. wide very irregular shores – from this isle went to the 1st pt on Rt ½ m. on the No shore, kept along it Wly abt 1m. to la premiere Port. de lac Eturgeon, it lies in a small bay on Rt a rock lying in ye Bay, & a large one close to ye Path. Port. is 300yds long & bad road being choak'd up with small woods. From the end of the Port. a small lac, turn'd 1st pt on L[t] & went WbN¾, having 2 bays on Rt & 2 on ye Lt – went to the end of ye lac (on Lt) to Port. de la discharge 340yds long & bad road, being swampy & choak'd up – then entd a small narr: lac, went in it abt ¾ m. to a Swamp (on Lt) in wch went abt ¾ men debark'd & pass'd the Canoe thro' it to another lac (had much trouble in ye Swamp, having scarce room eno[ugh] for ye Canoe, here is a path on ye Rt along which carried part of our things)[.] Leaving the Swamp pass'd rod 1st pt on Lt ¼ m – then entd a Chanl abt 100yds wide to the 1st pt on Rt w[½] turn'd ye Pt into another Channel WNW to a pt on Lt 2m.[,] here the lac opens large w[th] sevl Is – then WbN to the pt of a small Id on Lt islands & a bay on each side[.] (Stopp'd by Rain at 10h ½ a.m.) WbN2½ a traverse to the pt on an Id lac spacious on both sides with large Is – then WNW1½ to a pt on Rt to a pt on Rt between 2 Is which appea[r] at a distance like a Strait, lac spacious & large Is – then WNW2 a pt on Rt 2m. lac spacious on both sides with Is on ye Lt – turn'd rod ye pt & came to le Grand Port. de lac Eturgeon 1750yds over part of the road good & part swampy, at the end of ye Port. is a swamp which runs into a lac – NbW½m. to a pt on Lt from the end of the swamp – then WbN½m. between a small I. & the main on ye Lt deep bay on ye Rt & sevl Isles – then 1m. WNW to a pt on Lt being a Traverse across ye lac, bay & sevl Ids on Rt & a bay on Lt[,] at the end of this Co is a narrow neck, a grassy pt on Rt then turn'd ye Pt on the Rt & went NWbN¼ to a pt on Lt[,] here entd a Channel like a Creek[,] long Grass on both sides, went in it abt 1m. when it draws narrow, & as almost stopt up with Reeds, & long Grass[,] went among it ¼ m. to Portage de Fort[.]

td.p:
L E G E N D :
in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
